abstract.p: Cameron lesions are linear erosions located at the neck of a hiatal hernia (HH) in patients with a large HH. The prevalence has been seen in up to 5% of patients with HH who undergo esophagogastroduodenoscopy, and they can be associated with overt gastrointestinal bleeding or anemia. These lesions occur due to vascular compression by the diaphragm in a large sliding HH. Histopathologic changes seen in the biopsy tissue of a Cameron lesion are due to ischemia, but this ischemia is reversible with treatment of HH. The existence of this entity and the histopathologic picture of a Cameron lesion is not well known to pathologists, and therefore, a microscopic picture of a Cameron lesion can be easily confused with ischemic gastritis. Ischemic gastritis is the result of atherosclerosis, usually seen in older people, unrelated to HH, and is not easily reversible. The authors received a gastric biopsy of a hiatal hernia without any associated clinical diagnosis of a Cameron lesion conveyed to the pathologist. This biopsy tissue showed ischemic changes in the gastric mucosa on microscopic examination. Diagnosis of ischemic gastritis was considered but ruled out after the case was discussed with the gastroenterologist. The correct diagnosis was made once the clinical diagnosis of HH with Cameron lesion (ie, a vertical red erosion) was made known to the pathologist. By reporting this case, the authors aim to increase awareness of Cameron lesion among pathologists so that they ask about the presence of a Cameron lesion before making the diagnosis of ischemic gastritis.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Hiatal hernia is a condition in which gastrointestinal tissue protrudes into the thoracic cavity of the chest through a defect in the diaphragmatic esophageal hiatus. Cameron lesions are gastric ulcers or linear erosions commonly observed at the neck of large hiatal hernias.1 The pathogenesis of Cameron lesions has been considered to be either mechanical trauma caused by diaphragmatic pressure on the occluded hiatal sac or ischemia or acid mucosal injury.2,3 Endoscopic imaging shows that, during normal respiration, mucosa at the hiatus rubs against adjacent tissue causing the lesions.1,3 Gastroenterologists know Cameron lesions, but the awareness of this entity is extremely low among general pathologists. By reporting this case, we want to make the general surgical pathologists aware of the existence of this entity.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 71-year-old female presented to the emergency department with dyspepsia and associated discomfort. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy showed a large sliding hiatal hernia. Careful inspection revealed a nonbleeding, superficial, linear erosion on the crests of the gastric folds overlying the diaphragmatic indentation (Figure 1). The presence of this linear erosion was not conveyed to the pathologist by the gastroenterologist.

caption.p: A linear erosion in the right center half of the image (a Cameron lesion)

sec.p: A biopsy of this lesion was submitted to the Surgical Pathology Department. Microscopic examination of the biopsied tissue showed superficial mucosal necrosis with erosion of surface epithelium, small amount of acute inflammatory exudate on the surface, lamina propria fibrosis, and a few micropits. These findings were indicative of ischemic gastritis (Figures 2 and 3). Trichrome stain confirmed the presence of lamina propria fibrosis (Figure 4). A preliminary diagnosis of ischemic gastritis was made, which was changed to the final diagnosis of Cameron lesion after the gastroenterologist disclosed the endoscopic findings.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Although the existence of Cameron lesions remains largely underrecognized in the field of general surgical pathology, these lesions are not at all uncommon. Cameron lesions have been noted in about 5% of patients with hiatal hernias who underwent endoscopic examination.3 Potential complications caused by Cameron lesions include acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding, iron deficiency anemia caused by chronic blood loss, and perforations of the ulcer.2-4 Incarceration of a hiatal hernia can result in severe ischemia, potentially resulting in gastric perforations with a mortality rate >60%.5 In a case like the one we have discussed, surgical intervention is a common and ultimately effective approach for treatment. Once the large HH has been treated, the associated gastric ulcerations can begin to heal.6

Microanatomical characterization of Cameron erosions shows markers of vascular obstruction indicative of ischemic gastropathy. These markers include the presence of hemorrhagic infiltrates, fibrin thrombi, inflammatory response, sanguine microsuffusions, sloughing of surface epithelial cells, atrophy of crypts, and areas of coagulation necrosis.3,7,8 Biopsies performed on patients diagnosed with chronic upper gastrointestinal ischemia (CUGI) present very similar microscopic characteristics to those with Cameron lesions. Van Noord et al9 studied the histological changes in patients diagnosed with CUGI, noting prominent histological changes that included gastric atrophy, fibrosis, necrosis, and infiltration by immune-related cells. Whereas the ischemia observed in Cameron lesions is simply a product of vascular compression by the diaphragm, chronic ischemic gastritis may imply abdominal arterial stenosis. As we have already mentioned, the suppression of local microvasculature at the opening of the hernia is reversible once the hiatal hernia is treated.5,10 Ischemic gastritis is the result of atherosclerosis, usually seen in older people, unrelated to HH, and is not easily reversible.9

We have reported histopathologic findings of ischemic gastritis in the biopsy specimen of a Cameron lesion. Although the gastroenterologist can understand the reason for ischemia in the biopsy specimen, the pathologist observing ischemic changes in a gastric biopsy may not know that he/she is dealing with a Cameron lesion. By reporting this case, we aim to increase the awareness of Cameron lesions among general surgical pathologists. When presented with a gastric biopsy that shows ischemic changes, the pathologist should first ask for the patient history and endoscopic findings before making the diagnosis of ischemic gastritis. Knowledge of the histological changes associated with Cameron lesions and the corresponding pathogenesis can help prevent a pathologist from making the incorrect diagnosis.
